sub_topic: The study of the properties of the top quark in different production modes
message_1: What are the differences in the production modes of top quarks in proton-proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider? Compare and analyze the properties of the top quark in these production modes, including cross-sections, kinematics, and decay channels. How do these differences help us better understand the nature of the top quark and its role in the Standard Model of particle physics?
message_2:
At the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), top quarks are predominantly produced in proton-proton (pp) collisions. There are three main production modes of top quarks at the LHC: pair production (t¯t), single top production, and associated production with other particles. We will discuss the properties of the top quark in these production modes, including cross-sections, kinematics, and decay channels, and how these differences help us better understand the nature of the top quark and its role in the Standard Model of particle physics.

1. Top quark pair production (t¯t):
The most common production mode of top quarks at the LHC is through top quark-antiquark pair production. This process occurs mainly via the strong interaction, involving the fusion of two gluons or the annihilation of a quark-antiquark pair. The cross-section for t¯t production at the LHC is relatively large, around 800 pb at a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV. The top quarks produced in this mode have a broad range of kinematic properties, including a wide range of transverse momenta and rapidities. The top quark decays almost exclusively into a W boson and a bottom quark (t → Wb), leading to various decay channels depending on the decay of the W boson (dileptonic, semileptonic, and fully hadronic).

2. Single top production:
Single top quarks can be produced via three main processes: t-channel, s-channel, and associated production with a W boson (tW). These processes occur through the electroweak interaction, involving the exchange of a virtual W boson. The cross-sections for single top production are smaller than for t¯t production, with the t-channel having the largest cross-section (around 250 pb at 13 TeV), followed by tW (around 50 pb) and s-channel (around 10 pb). The kinematic properties of single top quarks are different from those in t¯t production, with a more forward rapidity distribution for the t-channel and a softer transverse momentum distribution for the s-channel and tW processes. The decay channels of single top quarks are the same as for t¯t production, as they also decay into a W boson and a bottom quark.

3. Associated production with other particles:
Top quarks can also be produced in association with other particles, such as vector bosons (W, Z, or photon) or Higgs bosons. These processes have smaller cross-sections compared to t¯t and single top production, but they are important for probing the electroweak properties of the top quark and its couplings to other particles. The kinematic properties and decay channels of top quarks in associated production depend on the specific process and the accompanying particles.

The differences in the production modes of top quarks at the LHC provide valuable information about the nature of the top quark and its role in the Standard Model of particle physics. By studying the cross-sections, kinematics, and decay channels of top quarks in various production modes, we can test the predictions of the Standard Model, probe the properties of the top quark (such as its mass, couplings, and spin), and search for new physics beyond the Standard Model. Furthermore, the precise measurement of top quark production processes can help improve our understanding of the strong and electroweak interactions, as well as the parton distribution functions of the proton.
